author: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
title: Biden’s Fraught Saudi Visit Garners Scathing Criticism and Modest Accords
description: In the most politically problematic trip of his presidency, Mr. Biden’s critics accused him of helping rehabilitate the reputation of a tarnished prince in exchange for numerous, but limited gains.
content: JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia — President Biden exchanged the shaken fist for a fist bump on Friday as he abandoned his promise to make Saudi Arabia a “pariah” and sat down with the crown prince he deemed responsible for the grisly killing and dismemberment of a columnist who lived in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Recommended Reading on America’s Authoritarian Enclaves
description: Joan Didion’s “Slouching Towards Bethlehem” and Robert Mickey’s “Paths Out of Dixie” help our columnist understand American democracy’s new crisis of authoritarianism.
content: This week I have been reading about the United States in the 1960s and 70s, staying up late going back through Joan Didion’s “Slouching Towards Bethlehem” and “The White Album,” and falling down rabbit holes of oral history interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Demand for Monkeypox Vaccine Exceeds Supply, C.D.C. Says
description: The United States has ordered nearly seven million doses in total, but most of them will not arrive for months.
content: As the monkeypox outbreak grows in the United States, demand for the vaccine is outstripping the nation’s supply, Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said at a news briefing on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Passes Two Bills Seeking to Ensure Access to Abortion
description: Neither piece of legislation has the votes to advance in the Senate, but Democrats intend them to draw clear lines on the issue for the midterm elections.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Friday passed two bills aiming at ensuring access to abortion in the post-Roe era, as Democrats seek to draw clear distinctions with Republicans on the issue heading into the midterm election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Ava Sasani
title: Doctor Informed State of 10-Year-Old Girl’s Abortion
description: A document obtained by The New York Times shows that the Indiana obstetrician reported the child’s abortion to the state.
content: A lawyer for the Indiana obstetrician who has drawn national attention for providing abortion care to a 10-year-old rape victim said on Thursday that the doctor had taken “every appropriate and proper action” in the case — including filing necessary forms to report the abortion with state authorities, contrary to the assertions of Indiana’s attorney general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Spencer
title: Daisy Edgar-Jones Would Like the Ingénue Phase of Her Career to End Now
description: The star of “Where the Crawdads Sing” and “Normal People” has quickly become a Hollywood “It” Girl. But what she craves is longevity.
content: Daisy Edgar-Jones bravely walked onstage, her face a ghastly white. Under her arm, a human head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Statue of Liberty Cruise Boat Captain Spends His Sundays
description: Matthew Gill takes thousands of tourists across New York Bay to visit the sites, including Ellis Island.
content: In 1998, Matthew Gill, a 14-year-old in Staten Island, got a summer job answering phones, giving directions and collecting tickets for City Experiences Statue City Cruises. Now 38, he’s still with the company, but he has moved up to port captain. Among his responsibilities on the water is the safe passage of thousands of tourists across New York Bay to visit Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Taking the Magic Out of Magic Mushrooms
description: Inside scientists’ efforts to capture the benefits of psychedelics without the trip.
content: Nick Fernandez was in hell — one filled with fire and skulls and the long-legged elephants from a Salvador Dalí painting. A spirit had guided him there after his funeral; other stops on their journey included Grand Central Terminal, the top of the Empire State Building and the sewers flowing beneath New York City. Their final destination was a cave where Mr. Fernandez encountered his own body, hung up on a clothes hanger. By examining his body in this way, he was able to come to peace with all that it had been through and accept it as his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
title: How One Senator Doomed the Democrats’ Climate Plan
description: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia led his party and his president through months of tortured talks, with nothing to show for it as the planet dangerously heats up.
content: WASHINGTON — First, he killed a plan that would have forced power plants to clean up their climate-warming pollution. Then, he shattered an effort to help consumers pay for electric vehicles. And, finally, he said he could not support government incentives for solar and wind companies or any of the other provisions that the rest of his party and his president say are vital to ensure a livable planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Shao
title: In a Twist, Old Coal Plants Help Deliver Renewable Power. Here’s How.
description: The sites, once a source of greenhouse gases, have a useful feature: They’re wired to the electricity grid. For new ventures like solar farms, that can save a lot of time and money.
content: Across the country, aging and defunct coal-burning power plants are getting new lives as solar, battery and other renewable energy projects, partly because they have a decades-old feature that has become increasingly valuable: They are already wired into the power grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: What Biden Got Right on His Trip to the Middle East
description: There is real value in making small steps through diplomacy.
content: Joe Biden campaigned and won as the antithesis to Donald Trump. To deliver on that promise in foreign policy, in his first year as president, he tried to offer “something for everyone,” as Anne-Marie Slaughter has argued: tough talk on China for the realists; a recommitment to NATO, to the Paris Agreement on climate, and to the World Health Organization for the liberal internationalists; an end to the forever wars; and, for the idealists, a willingness to speak up for human rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Ask a Flight Attendant About Flying Now
description: Whether you have travel anxieties or you’re just curious about what really goes on behind the curtain, you can finally get your questions answered.
content: Flying can be a high-stress activity now. What if my flight gets canceled? What if the airline loses my luggage? On top of airline dramas, the risk of Covid-19 while traveling still looms uneasily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and McKenna Oxenden
title: Judge Clears Former New Mexico Officer in Chokehold Death
description: A trial judge dismissed a second-degree murder charge against the former officer, Christopher Smelser, in the death of Antonio Valenzuela, 40, during a traffic stop in Las Cruces.
content: A judge in New Mexico on Thursday cleared a former police officer who was accused of killing a man by using a chokehold technique, a practice that has come under intense scrutiny in recent years amid calls for police reform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Mark Fleischman, the Last Impresario of Studio 54, Dies at 82
description: He took over the celebrated Manhattan club in the early 1980s and briefly became the self-described “ringleader” of an all-night circus.
content: Mark Fleischman, who presided over the raucous, drug-crazed denouement of the celebrity-studded Manhattan disco Studio 54 in the early 1980s, died on Wednesday in Switzerland. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Biden Administration Retreats on Threat to Withhold Arizona Relief Funds
description: Treasury disbursed $2.1 billion in pandemic aid after warning it could be withheld because the state had used aid money to undercut school mask mandates.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration backed off its threat to withhold pandemic aid money from Arizona after accusing the state earlier this year of misusing the funds to undercut school mask mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Cryptomining Capacity in U.S. Rivals Energy Use of Houston, Findings Show
description: The findings, by a congressional investigation, highlight how the surge in activity has caused consumers’ electrical bills to rise and makes it harder to fight global warming.
content: Seven of the largest Bitcoin mining companies in the United States are set up to use nearly as much electricity as the homes in Houston, according to data disclosed Friday as part of an investigation by congressional Democrats who say miners should be required to report their energy use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Make the Most of Too Much Summer Squash With the Zucchini Slice
description: Popular in Australia and New Zealand, this cross between a frittata and savory quick bread is perhaps even better than either on its own.
content: If the phrase “zucchini slice” conjures an image of a round of the raw vegetable sitting next to the onion dip, it’s only because you haven’t been to Australia or New Zealand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Seo
title: How to Stay Hydrated in a Heat Wave
description: Many countries across the globe are facing dangerously high temperatures. Here’s what to do to stay safe.
content: Large swaths of the United States, as well as many parts of Europe, China and other areas worldwide, are facing dangerous levels of heat. That means that many people who live in affected regions will need to be especially vigilant about keeping themselves safe and healthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Dear Friends and Strangers
description: When you’re stuck in an existential rut and a stranger needs a kidney.
content: What prompts someone to donate a kidney to a stranger?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Deshaun Watson’s Accusers Settle Their Claims Against the Texans
description: Thirty women reached settlements with the team Watson played for when he was accused of sexual misconduct during massage appointments. Four lawsuits against Watson are outstanding.
content: The Houston Texans have reached settlements with 30 women who have accused the N.F.L. quarterback Deshaun Watson of sexual misconduct in massage appointments, according to Tony Buzbee, the lawyer representing the women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein and Vanessa Friedman
title: Sables and Minks and Chinchillas Galore: Ivana Trump’s Opulent Style
description: Dennis Basso, a longtime friend and furrier, recalls his many collaborations with the first Ms. Trump.
content: “Ivana Trump’s look wasn’t for everyone,” the designer Dennis Basso said Thursday afternoon, a few hours after Ms. Trump’s death was announced by former President Donald J. Trump, her ex-husband, in a statement posted on his social networking platform, Truth Social.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Prosecutor Warns Georgia Officials They May Face Charges in Trump Inquiry
description: The investigation could prove to be one of the most perilous legal problems facing the former president and his allies.
content: ATLANTA — The breadth, speed and seriousness of the criminal investigation into election meddling by former President Donald J. Trump and his associates in Georgia were underscored on Friday by the revelation that two pro-Trump state senators and the chair of the state Republican Party were sent letters by an Atlanta prosecutor informing them they could be indicted, according to a person familiar with the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel to Dissect Trump’s 187 Minutes of Inaction During Riot
description: The House committee investigating the attack announced it would hold its next hearing on Thursday in prime time. It was not clear whether it would be the summer finale, as once expected.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol is planning to return to prime time on Thursday for what could be the finale of its summer hearing schedule: a session focused on former President Donald J. Trump’s 187 minutes of inaction as a mob of his supporters assaulted Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley, Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
title: Biden Concedes Defeat on Climate Bill as Manchin and Inflation Upend Agenda
description: Rising prices, party infighting and the aftershocks from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine have undercut the president’s plans to speed an energy transition.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden bowed to political reality on Friday, conceding that he had been unable to persuade a holdout coal-state Democrat, or any Republicans in the Senate, to back legislation that had been his greatest hope to confront the climate crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Arsenault
title: Civil Rights Memoirs
description: Three new books describe Blacks engaged in politics in the South.
content: A WAY OUT OF NO WAYA Memoir of Truth, Transformation, and the New American StoryBy Raphael G. Warnock288 pp. Penguin Press. $28.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang and Anton Troianovski
title: In Space, U.S.-Russian Cooperation Finds a Way Forward
description: The two countries’ astronauts will swap seats on each other’s rockets, and Vladimir Putin dismissed the leader of the Russian space agency, who had become known for bellicose outbursts.
content: When SpaceX next launches a Falcon 9 rocket to the International Space Station, one of the astronauts aboard will be Russian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Democratic Primaries Are Embroiled in Debate Over Support for Israel
description: A primary on Tuesday in suburban Maryland is the latest where pro-Israel groups have stepped in to try to defeat a candidate who doesn’t conform to their views.
content: OXON HILL, Md. — The primary on Tuesday for a Maryland House seat outside Washington would seem to be an ideologically monochromatic affair between two experienced, liberal lawyers who hope to represent a Democratic swath of predominantly Black middle-class suburbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: YoungBoy Never Broke Again Found Not Guilty in Federal Gun Case
description: Lawyers for the rapper argued that he did not know the weapon was in his car when he was pulled over and arrested on a separate warrant in California last year.
content: The chart-topping 22-year-old rapper YoungBoy Never Broke Again, born Kentrell D. Gaulden, was found not guilty on Friday of possessing a firearm and ammunition as a felon, concluding one of the two federal gun trials he had been facing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Drug Kingpin Convicted of Killing D.E.A. Agent Is Captured in Mexico
description: Rafael Caro Quintero, an accused drug cartel leader, was convicted of killing Enrique Camarena, a Drug Enforcement Administration agent, and was wanted by the F.BI.
content: MEXICO CITY — A drug kingpin convicted of orchestrating the torture and murder of a Drug Enforcement Administration agent was captured in northern Mexico on Friday, according to Mexican officials, bringing a case that has long been a source of tension with the United States one step closer to resolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Only Saudi Arabia and Israeli Arabs Can Save Israel as a Jewish Democracy
description: An existential question continues to haunt Israel.
content: It is great to see President Biden visiting the Middle East. America has long played a vital role in advancing the peace process there. But as someone who has followed this region for decades, I can tell you that I’m seeing something new, something that is as ironic as it is surprising: Only Saudi Arabia and the Israeli Arabs can save Israel as a Jewish democracy today — not America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Gray
title: It’s Been a Poor Year So Far for Municipal Bonds
description: Still, investors may have cause for optimism since yields on the bonds are rising and many state and local governments are financially flush.
content: The big perk of municipal bonds is that they are exempt from federal taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Dan Barry
title: What Is the Free State Project?
description: Our guest writer Dan Barry explains the history behind a New Hampshire movement whose temporary victory galvanized a small town.
content: Today’s newsletter is a guest dispatch from Dan Barry, who wrote in The New York Times on Sunday about how the surprise victory of a hardcore libertarian movement in a small New Hampshire town led to swift backlash — and a harsh lesson in the importance of showing up to vote. Here, Dan explains the group behind the clash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Crisis in Draghi Government Dismays Italians
description: The prime minister’s success in expanding Italy’s influence left many disbelieving that a part of his coalition would knock the country back onto wobbly footing.
content: ROME — The stunning announcement by Prime Minister Mario Draghi that he would resign after a rebellion in his national unity government left Italians alarmed and dismayed on Friday, and bitten by a deep sense of uncertainty over where the country was now headed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Jason Gutierrez
title: Smile or Be Disciplined, Philippine Mayors Warn City Workers
description: “Frowning is not allowed in the municipality!” said the mayor of Mulanay in the Philippines. Many residents applauded his new policy.
content: Soon after taking office last month as mayor of a town in the northern Philippines, Aristotle Aguirre signed an order to fulfill one of his campaign promises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: As Israelis praise Biden, some Palestinians protest over his visit.
description: Demonstrators express frustration with Washington’s support for Israel and the Biden administration’s policies toward Palestinians.
content: Palestinians protested on Friday in Jerusalem and Bethlehem over President Biden’s visit as he met with the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, amid widespread frustration with U.S. support for Israel and the Biden administration’s policies toward Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Maxwell
title: A Country Refuge for London Creatives
description: Somerset has re-emerged as an English weekend idyll, with inspired restaurants, stately homes turned hotels and contemporary art institutions.
content: Welcome to T Wanderlust, a new travel newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Twice a month, we’ll recommend global destinations and hotels worth visiting. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every other Friday, along with our T List newsletter each Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: For Two Octogenarians, the ‘Endgame’ Was Just the Beginning
description: Hours into their first date last December, Jack Pinto asked Joan Klein a question: “So, what is your endgame?” Within seven months, they were husband and wife.
content: On their first date last December, Joan Marie Klein made a confession to Jack William Pinto: She was not 79-years-old, as she had said, but 87.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kim Stanley Robinson
description: A conversation with science fiction writer Kim Stanley Robinson.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kim Stanley Robinson. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: This Home-Renovation Show Wants to Get You Into Bed
description: The new Netflix series “How to Build a Sex Room” doesn’t just indulge fantasies. It helps people rediscover some intimacy in their homes.
content: As far as home improvements go, sex rooms are not generally considered smart financial investments. What future buyer would want anything to do with someone else’s adults-only romper room?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Beto O’Rourke broke a Texas fund-raising record with a $27.6 million haul, his campaign said.
description: Gov. Greg Abbott, the Republican incumbent who maintains an advantage in cash on hand, raised nearly $25 million over the same period.
content: Beto O’Rourke set a new Texas fund-raising record for state office with a $27.6 million haul over four months in the governor’s race, his campaign announced on Friday, saying that it had outpaced Gov. Greg Abbott, the Republican incumbent, in the tightening contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Four Ways the United States Can Still Fight Climate Change
description: With the president’s most potent tools to fight climate change stripped by Congress and the courts, the administration will now have to rely on smaller, less powerful actions.
content: WASHINGTON — With the largest and most powerful tools that President Biden had hoped to use to fight climate change now stripped away, the White House is assembling smaller, less potent policies that could still help the nation reduce its planet-warming pollution, though not at the levels that Mr. Biden once promised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: German Military Officer Known as Franco A. Found Guilty of Plotting Terrorism
description: The officer, who had posed as a Syrian refugee, was sentenced to five and a half years in prison for a far-right plot to assassinate prominent public figures.
content: FRANKFURT — In one of postwar Germany’s most spectacular terrorism trials, a military officer who had posed as a Syrian refugee was sentenced to five and a half years in prison on Friday for plotting to assassinate prominent politicians and public figures in the hopes of bringing down the country’s democratic order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalia Richardson
title: 200 Years Later, Charleston Honors Denmark Vesey’s Attempted Uprising
description: Vesey tried to organize an insurrection in 1822 to free enslaved people, but was caught and hanged. Now several prominent Charleston institutions are honoring the bicentenary.
content: Denmark Vesey, a formerly enslaved man who bought his freedom after winning the lottery, tried to organize a slave rebellion in Charleston, S.C., in 1822, making plans to execute white enslavers and sail to freedom in Haiti. But Charleston authorities halted the insurrection and hanged Vesey, along with nearly three dozen others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Voting access updates: Mail ballots are at issue as states consider new rules and legal action.
description: A signature-matching rule in North Carolina is rejected, mail ballots in Pennsylvania are in dispute, and more.
content: As the nation prepares for yet another pandemic election, the rules for voting by mail remain a flash point in many states, a conflict that is being waged in courtrooms and state houses over Republican-backed restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Russian strikes on Ukrainian civilians.
content: A volley of Russian strikes yesterday morning on Vinnytsia, a city that had a prewar population of about 370,000 people in central Ukraine, killed at least 23 people, including three children. Late that evening, at least as many others were still lost in the rubble. In the attack, three Kalibr cruise missiles were launched from a submarine in the Black Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: As U.S. Covid hospitalizations climb, a chronic nursing shortage is worsening.
description: Hospitals across the country continue to struggle to hire and retain enough nurses, as the spread of the BA.5 subvariant adds to caseloads.
content: American hospitals are once again filling up with coronavirus patients — but not with nurses to care for them. The nation’s chronic shortage of registered nurses is as bad in some parts of the country as it has ever been, experts say, and it is showing signs of getting worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Vaccine protection waned this spring but boosters helped, the C.D.C. reports.
description: “Booster doses should be obtained immediately when persons become eligible,” the C.D.C. scientists wrote.
content: The emergence of highly contagious Omicron subvariants this spring in the United States appeared to reduce the protection offered by vaccines against Covid hospitalizations, scientists from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Brittney Griner’s lawyers say she had a prescription for the drug she mistakenly carried into Russia.
description: As the W.N.B.A. star’s drugs trial resumed, her defense team contended that she had packed a banned narcotic in her luggage because of “an oversight.”
content: Brittney Griner’s lawyers argued on Friday that the American basketball star had a medical prescription for the drug that she mistakenly carried into Russia, where she has been detained for nearly five months amid Moscow’s escalating tensions with Washington over the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Talking to the Dead Through Voice Mail: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Nikole Hannah-Jones and University Settle Hiring Dispute
description: Ms. Hannah-Jones, who won a Pulitzer Prize for the 1619 Project, had said she was considering legal action against the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
content: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill has reached a settlement with Nikole Hannah-Jones, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist for The New York Times Magazine, after a dispute over tenure, the school said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Lefton
title: Baseball’s Efforts in China May Show Up at the Draft
description: Players from China have signed as international free agents, but a new wave of recruits is trying a different path: attending a U.S. college to become eligible for the draft.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — None of the hundred or so fans at a recent Ban Johnson summer collegiate league game here felt compelled to leap from their lawn chairs to applaud when a batter, known just by the nickname DJ, stopped at second base on a ball he had ripped down the first-base line. It was a routine play that required DJ, the team’s fastest runner, to suppress his desire to leg out a triple in favor of doing what the situation dictated rather than risking an inning-ending out at third.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Republicans Are Already Threatening the Right to Travel
description: Dobbs has them all fired up.
content: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, it did more than just supercharge the assault on the right to have an abortion. It also opened up a corresponding attack on the right to travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Amy Qin
title: China’s Leader Visits Xinjiang for the First Time Since Imposing Crackdown
description: State media have used Xi Jinping’s visits to Hong Kong and, now, Xinjiang to bolster his image as a leader who subdued turbulence on China’s periphery.
content: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, made his first visit to the western region of Xinjiang since he unleashed a campaign of mass detentions of Uyghurs there. His trip amounted to a proclamation of success in his yearslong effort to quell ethnic resistance, in spite of international condemnation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Kate Conger and Matthew Goldstein
title: Elon Musk Claps Back at Twitter’s Lawsuit Over $44 Billion Deal
description: Mr. Musk formally responded to Twitter’s attempt to force him to buy the company, arguing that there was no reason to hurry the case.
content: Elon Musk accused Twitter on Friday of deceiving him about its service, obfuscating facts and not notifying him of executive changes, in his first formal response to the company’s lawsuit aimed at forcing him to complete a $44 billion acquisition of the social media service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: What Is … Happily Ever After?
description: Sarah Bauer and Greer Mackebee met as contestants in the 2012 “Jeopardy! National College Championship.” Years later, the one-time competitors became a couple.
content: “Stringing along,” “states by attractions” and “famous pairs” were among the categories on the episode of “Jeopardy!” that featured Sarah Elizabeth Bauer and William Greer Mackebee as contestants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Stubson
title: Liz Cheney’s Last Stand
description: To win, Representative Liz Cheney will need moderate Wyoming voters.
content: CASPER, Wyo. — On the same day in June that Representative Liz Cheney was making the case to the nation that Donald Trump was responsible for the Jan. 6 insurrection, members of the Natrona County Republican central committee crammed into a hotel conference room to debate whether Jan. 6 was a big deal at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Sharp Drop in Childhood Vaccinations Threatens Millions of Lives
description: Pandemic lockdowns, misinformation campaigns, conflicts, climate crises and other problems diverted resources and contributed to the largest backslide in routine immunization in 30 years.
content: Millions of children around the world, most of them in the poorest countries, missed some or all of their childhood vaccinations over the past two years because of a combination of conflicts, climate emergencies, misinformation campaigns, pandemic lockdowns and Covid vaccination efforts that diverted resources, according to a new analysis from Unicef, the United Nations agency that vaccinates half the world’s children, and the World Health Organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Man Posing as Officer Attacked Gay Men in a Washington Park, Prosecutors Say
description: Michael Thomas Pruden, 48, sprayed five men at Meridian Hill Park with a chemical irritant over three years while pretending to be a Park Police officer, the Justice Department said.
content: A Maryland man has been indicted on assault charges accusing him of pretending to be a police officer and spraying five men who he believed were gay with a chemical irritant at a park in Washington, the Justice Department said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim, Matthew Futterman and Scott Cacciola
title: The Top Races to Watch at the Track and Field World Championships
description: The fastest runners in the world are converging in Eugene, Ore., for the next 10 days.
content: The World Athletics Championships open Friday in Eugene, Ore., the crunchy university town that calls itself TrackTown, U.S.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Ivana Trump’s Death Is Ruled Accidental
description: Ms. Trump, an ex-wife of former President Donald J. Trump, died by blunt impact injuries, according to New York City’s chief medical examiner.
content: Ivana Trump, the ex-wife of former president Donald J. Trump, died accidentally of blunt impact injuries to her torso, according to New York City’s chief medical examiner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Biden’s Mideast Message: Good News for Israel, Small Steps for Palestinians
description: To Israelis, President Biden’s visit was mostly a source of celebration of growing ties with Arab countries. For the Palestinians, Mr. Biden brought funding and sympathy — but no long-term plans.
content: JERUSALEM — President Biden had contrasting messages for Israelis and Palestinians on Friday before departing Israel for Saudi Arabia, announcing new steps toward Israeli integration within the Middle East while cautioning Palestinians that now was not the time for new peace talks to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: 5 Smart Comedy Specials From Veteran Standups
description: Joel Kim Booster, Nikki Glaser, Bill Burr, Fahim Anwar and Cristela Alonzo deliver strong hours ideal for summer viewing.
content: Why isn’t there a standup-special equivalent of a beach read? I wouldn’t recommend sunbathing with a smartphone in your hand, but it’s certainly possible. As more comics release their first specials developed in the pandemic, a new crop of hours from seasoned acts is ready to complement your summer vacation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Biden Drops Plan to Name Anti-Abortion Lawyer Backed by McConnell as Judge
description: The White House quietly agreed with the Senate Republican leader to nominate Chad Meredith for a federal judgeship, but opposition from his fellow Kentuckian Rand Paul scuttled the deal.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House is abandoning plans to nominate a Kentucky lawyer who opposes abortion rights and is backed by Senator Mitch McConnell to a federal court seat, citing opposition from Senator Rand Paul, Mr. McConnell’s home-state colleague.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: With Tears and Hat Tips, Woods Bids Farewell, Perhaps, to St. Andrews
description: Tiger Woods missed the cut at the British Open, ending, he knows, what might have been his last competitive tournament on his favorite course.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The roars at last ebbed when Tiger Woods reached his ball, if only because everyone knew the clamor could start again soon enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Paula Mónaco Felipe, Caroline Kim, Souleyman Messalti and Miguel Tovar
title: Mexican Activists Answer Calls for Abortion Pills From the U.S.
description: As more U.S. states move to criminalize abortion, activists in Mexico have been inundated with calls from women seeking abortion medication. Our cameras went inside their distribution effort.
content: In the weeks since the U.S. Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to abortion, the phones and social media accounts of abortion rights activists in Mexico have been inundated with desperate requests for abortion pills from people in the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Russia hammers Mykolaiv again, hitting two universities in the southern city.
description: At least 10 Russian missiles slammed into Mykolaiv, local officials said on Friday, hitting two universities, a hotel and a mall in the center of the southern Ukrainian city, which has been in Moscow’s cross hairs since President Vladimir V. Putin’s forces invaded in February.
content: At least 10 Russian missiles slammed into Mykolaiv, local officials said on Friday, hitting two universities, a hotel and a mall in the center of the southern Ukrainian city, which has been in Moscow’s cross hairs since President Vladimir V. Putin’s forces invaded in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Texas and its power system prepare for more high temperatures.
description: Readings of 100 or more are forecast throughout the coming week in much of the state.
content: After several days when triple-digit temperatures tested the ability of the Texas electric grid to keep power flowing, another round of extreme heat threatens the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: An American Climate Failure
description: The collapse of climate legislation is a blow to global efforts to address warming.
content: As millions of people on three continents baked in heat waves supercharged by climate change this week, one American politician, an ardent champion of the fossil fuel industry, doused any hopes of immediate climate action in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Brittney Griner Is Trapped and Alone. Where’s Your Outrage?
description: Where is the groundswell of support, demanding that Brittney Griner be brought home now?
content: When unspeakable tragedies occur, people often call for unity. They’ll say, “We are Boston Strong” or “Je suis Charlie” or “We are [insert wherever or whomever the unthinkable has happened to].” It’s a laudable instinct to claim solidarity with those who have suffered, to imagine we truly understand the ways we are all connected, to proclaim that what affects one of us affects all of us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: China’s Economic Covid Slump
description: The country’s continued lockdowns are having consequences on its ability to do business.
content: China’s economic engine is shuddering. The country’s National Bureau of Statistics said today that the economy expanded by only 0.4 percent in the second quarter. It was smaller than expected and the lowest growth since the early months of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Largest Study to Date Shows How Covid Vaccines Affect Periods
description: For some, a side effect of getting vaccinated was a change in menstrual cycles — but experts say there is no cause for alarm.
content: Nearly half of the participants of a recent study who were menstruating regularly at the time of the survey reported heavier bleeding during their periods after receiving the Covid-19 vaccine. Others who did not typically menstruate — including transgender men, people on long-acting contraceptives, and post-menopausal women — also experienced unusual bleeding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australia Shifts Its Tone at the Pacific Islands Forum
description: Australia, which has been accused of taking a dismissive stance in the past toward island nations, spent the week trying to “show respect” and build its influence.
content: By many accounts, the Pacific Islands Forum was a success for Australia. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was full of assurances when he assessed his meetings with island leaders earlier this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Manchin Dangles Hopes of a Future Compromise. Democrats Revolt.
description: A day after the West Virginia senator scuttled plans to pass a climate and tax package, many in his party blamed him for the demise of their ambitions and expressed a lack of trust in him.
content: WASHINGTON — It was a familiar, if excruciating, position for Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce and Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Above the Delaware River, a Double Wedding Straddling State Lines
description: Patricia Parent and Philip Kuntz had been double dating with Kelly Heflin and Carol McNitt for about a year when they hatched a plan to marry together on a bridge between New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
content: Philip Andrew Kuntz and Patricia Lynn Parent first met as across-the-street neighbors in Parsippany, N.J., when both were 3 years old. “She wasn’t exactly the girl next door, but,” Mr. Kuntz said, “close enough.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: This Manhattan Park Was Once a Gem. Now It’s a ‘No Man’s Land.’
description: A decades-long fight to reopen a park house, once a thriving community center in a working-class neighborhood, has taken on new urgency during the pandemic.
content: There was always something to do at the red brick park house with the big inviting archways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Piccoli and Ed Shanahan
title: 3 Imprisoned for Fiery 1995 Subway Murder Are Exonerated
description: The three men were convicted as teenagers for killing a subway token clerk after setting the booth ablaze, but New York police detectives elicited false confessions from them, prosecutors say.
content: The killing was shocking even for a New York City awash in violence at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: China’s Economy Hits a Slump as Covid Policy Takes a Toll
description: High unemployment, a housing market in crisis and sluggish consumer spending during lockdowns are putting pressure on Beijing in a year when officials are focused on projecting stability.
content: When countries around the world have stumbled in the face of pandemic headwinds, China has often stood apart, seemingly impervious to financial pressures that undermined growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: The War in Ukraine Is the True Culture War
description: With Russia trying to erase Ukraine’s national identity, the fight to preserve, and build upon, Ukraine’s artistic heritage has taken on new urgency.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — At the thousand-year-old Cathedral of Saint Sophia here, standing on an easel in front of a towering Baroque golden altar, is a new, freshly painted icon that’s just a foot square.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Andrew E. Kramer
title: In a Flash of Fire and Shrapnel, a Smiling 4-Year-Old’s Life Is Snuffed Out
description: A toddler with Down syndrome was happily pushing a stroller through a Ukraine park before a Russian missile landed. “I want to shout out to the whole world,” an anguished survivor of the attack cried.
content: VINNYTSIA, Ukraine — They called her Sunny Flower. She had just learned her first words. She liked to clean the corridor at the speech therapy center she attended, and organize the toys. She always seemed happy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Bat Virus Studies Raise Questions About Laboratory Tinkering
description: Working in a laboratory in Paris, scientists gave a close relative of the Covid virus the chance to evolve to be more like its cousin.
content: In mid-2020, a team of scientists catching bats in Laotian caves discovered coronaviruses that were strikingly similar to the one that had begun wreaking havoc around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Christine Quinn of ‘Selling Sunset’ Has Caviar for Breakfast
description: The villainous reality TV star and real estate agent has a taste for luxury.
content: Christine Quinn dipped a mother-of-pearl spoon into the bowl resting in its ice bath. Spreading caviar across a blini, she lifted the bite to her rose gold lips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: The many parties involved complicate war crimes investigations.
description: Russian attacks on civilians have underscored the need to hold war crimes to account. But the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court warned against a “stampede” of investigations.
content: A Russian missile strike on a city in central Ukraine on Thursday killed at least 23 people, including three children. Two weeks earlier, missiles crashed into buildings near Odesa, killing 21. And for weeks in the Kyiv suburb of Bucha, civilians bore the brunt of Russia’s assault — killed on their bicycles or while walking down the street, or executed with their hands bound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At the British Open, It’s the PGA Tour Faithful Against LIV Golf
description: “Everybody, it feels like, is against us, and that’s OK,” said Talor Gooch, a LIV golfer tied for eighth at seven under after the second round. Cameron Smith held the lead at 13 under par.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Tiger Woods was finishing up at the Old Course on Friday, perhaps for good, and Rory McIlroy was just getting started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and McKenna Oxenden
title: 2 Arrested in String of Fatal 7-Eleven Robberies, Police Say
description: The crimes, which occurred at six 7-Eleven stores in Southern California on Monday, left two dead and three others injured, the authorities said.
content: Two Los Angeles men were arrested on Friday in connection with a string of robberies at 7-Eleven stores in Southern California on Monday in which two people were fatally shot and three others injured in a crime spree that terrorized the region, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Handy
title: If A.I. Generated Book Jackets Based on Literary Titles…
description: This is why we don’t trust algorithms to design hardcovers.
content: The internet has been having fun of late with DALL-E Mini, newly renamed craiyon, an A.I. program that generates images in response to user suggestions. Type in a description of anything — even just the word “anything” — and DALL-E Mini will synthesize multiple images of it. An open-source software (inspired by the OpenAI technology DALL-E), it seems to work best, and most amusingly, with fanciful but concrete prompts; recent examples highlighted on a Twitter feed devoted to the subject include “the Last Supper in a strip club” and “dashcam footage of a hamster Godzilla wearing a giant sombrero hat attacking Tokyo.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: A New Palestinian Leader Rises in the West Bank. He’s Very Unpopular.
description: Hussein al-Sheikh is considered a possible successor to Mahmoud Abbas, 87, the Palestinian Authority president. But as a liaison to Israel, some critics call him a “spokesman of the occupation.”
content: RAMALLAH, West Bank — For years, Hussein al-Sheikh has overseen the fraught day-to-day relations between Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and the Israeli military — a role that has made him unpopular with the public but has drawn him close to the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Saudis Made Trump’s Visit an Extravaganza.
description: The Saudis lavished attention on President Donald J. Trump during his first visit in 2017, but President Biden has been more critical of the kingdom.
content: When President Donald J. Trump chose Saudi Arabia in 2017 for the first overseas trip of his presidency, the Saudis were so overjoyed that they turned his visit into a pro-American extravaganza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Stanley
title: Stop Ruining Starry Nights
description: Neighborhoods, including rural ones, are getting brighter. That’s not a good thing, according to our writer. What is the point of an illuminated shrub at 2 a.m.?
content: After over a decade of living in the city, I chose the plot of land, a flat patchwork of pine and oak at the base of the Catskill Mountains, for its terrible lighting. The area so dark, I could watch the champagne fizz of shooting stars from my bedroom window; catch a glimpse of the harvest moon while brushing my teeth. Every evening, the night pressed in against my windows in a way that felt visceral, like a velvet blanket tucking me in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: After 350 Years of Tradition, a Boys’ Choir Now Admits Girls
description: The Choir of St. John’s College, Cambridge, is the latest English choir to start including female singers, a move some fear will reduce opportunities for boys.
content: CAMBRIDGE, England — At 8 a.m. one recent Thursday, the boys of the Choir of St. John’s College, Cambridge, stifled yawns as they began their first rehearsal of the day with some vocal exercises. Soon, the room was filled with a host of “Ooo” and “Zah” sounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Agee
title: When First We Practice to Deceive
description: Lying and “breaking and entering” are the alleged crimes at the heart of three witty new picture books.
content: If children share one great talent it’s their ability to make things up. We encourage it because it sparks creativity. But at the same time we know making things up isn’t far from telling a lie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: The president said he rebuked the Saudi crown prince for the murder of Jamal Khashoggi.
description: Mr. Khashoggi, a Saudi contributor to The Washington Post who was critical of the prince’s rule, was killed in Istanbul in 2018.
content: President Biden said Friday night that he brought up the murder of Jamal Khashoggi during his closed-door meeting with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and told the prince that he considered him to blame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: A Weird, Wonderful Conversation With Kim Stanley Robinson
description: The sci-fi giant explains why he’s feeling more hopeful about the planet.
content: Kim Stanley Robinson is one of the great living science fiction writers and one of the most astute observers of how planets look, feel and work. His Mars Trilogy imagined what it might be like for humans to settle on the red planet. His best-selling novel “The Ministry for the Future” is a masterful effort at envisioning what might happen to Earth in a future of unchecked climate change. Robinson has a rare command of both science and human nature, and his writing crystallizes how the two must work together if we are to rescue our collective planetary future from possible ruin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Warped Fabric
description: Matthew Stock and Nam Jin Yoon bring both the new and the old to their Friday puzzle.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — After I solve the crosswords that I write about, I usually hop over to XWord Info, a website run by Jim Horne — the original Wordplay columnist — and the constructor Jeff Chen. That’s where I find all sorts of helpful analyses about New York Times puzzles, as well as comparisons to crosswords from our archives.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Across U.S., It’s Getting Harder to Find a Home
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 15, 2022.
content: “It’s like the cancer was limited to certain parts of our economic body. And now it’s spreading.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Son of Elsewhere’ Recounts Life as a Young Immigrant
description: Elamin Abdelmahmoud talks about his new memoir, and Sally Denton discusses “The Colony: Faith and Blood in a Promised Land.”
content: In “Son of Elsewhere,” Elamin Abdelmahmoud writes about growing up in Canada after moving there from Sudan when he was 12. On this week’s podcast, he talks about that experience, including his first interactions with his new peers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Lydia DePillis
title: Voters See a Bad Economy, Even if They’re Doing OK
description: A New York Times/Siena poll shows remarkable pessimism despite the labor market’s resilience. That could be costly for the Democrats, and the economy.
content: The fastest inflation in four decades has Americans feeling dour about the economy, even as their own finances have, so far, held up relatively well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Soprano Withdraws From Opera, Citing ‘Blackface’ in Netrebko’s ‘Aida’
description: The American soprano Angel Blue said she would not appear at the Arena di Verona after the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko and other performers wore dark makeup in its production of “Aida.”
content: A leading American soprano, Angel Blue, announced this week that she was withdrawing from her planned debut at the Arena di Verona in Italy to protest its use of “blackface makeup” in a production of Verdi’s “Aida” that starred the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: The Surprise Proposal That She (Kind of) Knew Was Coming
description: Suzanna Sone had two priorities for a proposal: for it to be a surprise, and to look cute in photos. To accommodate both, James Xi concocted an elaborate plan that involved dozens of her friends.
content: It wasn’t long after James Yihua Xi and Suzanna S. Sone arrived at the Washington dive bar he had suggested for their first date in February 2019 when Mr. Xi realized the location was all wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: I Need a Summer Hat That Isn’t a Baseball Cap. What Should I Wear?
description: Hats have become a semiological minefield. A reader wonders how to navigate it.
content: Once upon a time, in the 19th and early 20th centuries, a hat was a basic part of an adult wardrobe — the finishing touch as one went out the door, serving as both protection and social uniform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Using Comedy to Push for Abortion Rights
description: Lizz Winstead, the “Daily Show” co-creator, has marshaled her contacts in the standup world to help supporters turn protest into action.
content: “Things are awesome — never better!” joked Lizz Winstead, the comedian, producer and abortion rights activist. “Sleeping well; no diarrhea. Things are awesome.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Staten Island Ferry Cuts Service as Virus Triggers Crew Shortages
description: Rush-hour trips will take about five minutes longer for the next couple of weeks.
content: The Staten Island Ferry system is temporarily running less frequently during rush hours because of a surge in coronavirus infections among staff members, a spokesman for the city’s transportation department said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: ‘Governors Are the C.E.O.s’: State Leaders Weigh Their Might
description: At a National Governors Association gathering, attendees from both parties speculated about 2024 at a moment of increasing frustration with Washington.
content: PORTLAND, Maine — A single senator put parts of President Biden’s domestic agenda in grave danger. The president’s approval ratings are anemic amid deep dissatisfaction with Washington. And as both Mr. Biden, 79, and Donald J. Trump, 76, signal their intentions to run for president again, voters are demanding fresh blood in national politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: David Dalton, Rock Writer Who Lived the Scene, Dies at 80
description: An early writer for Rolling Stone, he traveled in the same circles as the Beatles, Janis Joplin and other stars, witnessing and documenting a time of cultural transformation.
content: David Dalton, who chronicled the rock scene as an early writer for Rolling Stone and brought firsthand knowledge to his biographies of rock stars from having lived the wild life alongside them, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: L.Q. Jones, Who Played Heavies With a Light Touch, Dies at 94
description: His face was familiar, mostly in westerns, during a career that spanned five decades. He also directed the cult film “A Boy and His Dog.”
content: L.Q. Jones, a hirsute, craggy-faced, swaggering Texan who guilelessly played the antihero in some 60 films and dozens of television series, died on Saturday at his home in the Hollywood Hills area of Los Angeles. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Maude Latour, a Columbia Student, Makes Existential Pop
description: The 22-year-old singer-songwriter just graduated with a degree in philosophy.
content: Name: Maude Latour
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron warns of ‘likely risk’ France will be cut off from Russian natural gas.
description: President Emmanuel Macron of France has warned that the country should brace itself for a total cutoff of Russian natural gas.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France has warned that the country should brace itself for a total cutoff of Russian natural gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: A Casual Fan’s Guide to This Year’s M.L.B. Draft
description: Druw Jones leads a talented field of second-generation prospects, there isn’t much pitching and no, you probably won’t see these guys in the majors very soon.
content: It will be a hectic weekend for Major League Baseball, which once again has packaged its annual first-year player draft with its other All-Star Game festivities. While not quite a made-for-TV event like its N.F.L. or N.B.A. equivalents, baseball’s draft is still vitally important for most clubs. Fans will just have to exercise some patience before getting excited about any of the players their favorite teams select.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Fretting Over Spelling and Fussing Over Spacing, On Deadline at the British Open
description: Garry Harvey, who once played the Open and now engraves the claret jug, has mere minutes to prepare one of the most famous trophies in sports as millions watch.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The good news for Garry Harvey is that almost no one in this year’s British Open field has a name quite as long as Severiano Ballesteros — Spanish master of the short game, three-time Open champion and unwitting menace to a man with minutes to engrave one of golf’s most sacred trophies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Lisa Friedman
title: Manchin Pulls Plug on Climate and Tax Talks, Shrinking Domestic Plan
description: The West Virginia Democrat’s decision dealt a crushing blow to President Biden’s domestic agenda, effectively ruling out action on anything beyond prescription drug pricing and health care subsidies.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, pulled the plug on Thursday on negotiations to salvage key pieces of President Biden’s agenda, informing his party’s leaders that he would not support funding for climate or energy programs or raising taxes on wealthy Americans and corporations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lora Kelley
title: Would You Pay $40 a Month to Have Strangers Watch You Work?
description: People still working remotely are turning to virtual co-working spaces for accountability through a Zoom screen.
content: At the start of a Caveday session, gentle music plays. A facilitator welcomes the participants — a group of strangers, there to work toward their personal goals — and may share inspirational quotes. It’s not yoga class. It’s a Zoom room and the dozens of people logged on have paid to work in silence for an hour or three with people they do not know looking on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: China’s Shuddering Economic Engine
description: Widespread lockdowns and mass quarantines in China has had far-reaching consequences for the global economy.
content: Good morning. Citigroup reported quarterly profits that beat analysts’ expectations, while BlackRock and Wells Fargo missed estimates. “Investors are simultaneously navigating high inflation, rising rates and the worst start to the year for both stocks and bonds in half a century,” said Larry Fink, BlackRock’s C.E.O. (Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Alex Tarquinio
title: Energy Was the Only Bright Spot in the Stock Market’s Gloom
description: But Russia’s war in Ukraine creates uncertainty about where energy funds will go in the second half of the year.
content: The energy industry has become the stock market’s equivalent of a road hog. As financial markets around the world fell this spring on worries about high inflation, rising interest rates and the strength of the economy, energy was the only sector gaining ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: The Meaning of the Plunging Euro
description: This time, a weak currency does reflect a weak economy.
content: In the summer of 2001, my wife and I took a cycling tour in Burgundy. We loved the scenery, the wine, the food (except for the andouillette — yuck) — and the prices. The still-new euro was at a low point, worth fewer than 90 U.S. cents, and everything in France looked cheap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz and Steve Eder
title: The U.S. Has a New Crisis Hotline: 988. Is It Prepared for a Surge in Calls?
description: The United States is rolling out a reimagined suicide prevention number to address a national mental health crisis. But funding and staffing issues have left some questioning whether it’s ready.
content: Americans in distress have a new number to dial for help — 988, a revamped National Suicide Prevention Lifeline that is being billed as the 911 of mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Build Back Better Is a Health Care Bill Now
description: Only two provisions in a once-sprawling social spending package have survived; they would lower prescription drug prices in Medicare and insurance premiums for millions of Americans.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Democrats in Congress had hoped to pass a broad domestic policy package that would expand the social safety net, raise taxes on corporations and the wealthiest Americans, and tighten regulation of climate-changing pollutants. But the decision by Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia to withdraw his support from other aspects of an already-shrunken package this week leaves nothing but health care on the table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: It’s the Summer for Sharks on Long Island Beaches
description: Climate change has sent sharks from the Chesapeake Bay up north to New York and New Jersey waters, a scientist said.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today it’s sharks and space — sharks off Long Island, and an auction of possessions that the astronaut Buzz Aldrin carried on the Apollo 11 moon mission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey A. Wilkinson
title: Dr. Caitlin Bernard Was Meant to Write This With Me Before She Was Attacked for Doing Her Job
description: It’s terrifying to be a doctor in post-Roe America.
content: Earlier this week I was preparing to write a guest essay with my colleague Dr. Caitlin Bernard, an OB-GYN here in Indiana. We wanted to write about the chilling effect that the overturning of Roe v. Wade has had on medicine in our state and around the country in just a few short weeks. But then Dr. Bernard became a target of a national smear campaign for speaking out about her 10-year-old patient, a rape victim from Ohio who needed an abortion and had to travel to Indiana to receive one, given the restrictions in her home state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon allow the passage of time.
content: ACROSTIC — I vaguely remember the original appearance of the passage in today’s puzzle; it was in a 2007 Vanity Fair series called “On the Limits of Self-Improvement.” Its author chronicled getting plumped, bleached and waxed into a smooth-skinned semblance of his former self, and regretting it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Shows Webb’s View of Something Closer to Home: Jupiter
description: The powerful telescope will help scientists make discoveries both within our solar system and well beyond it.
content: The new James Webb Space Telescope can capture photographs not only of galaxies across the universe, but also of objects in our celestial backyard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Comic-Con issues a mask mandate, not the costume kind, for next week’s event in San Diego.
description: Organizers said they expected more than 135,000 people at the convention, while the community level of Covid-19 in the county is high, according to the C.D.C.
content: Comic-Con International, which considers itself the oldest pop-culture convention in the world, is returning to San Diego for its first major in-person event since before the coronavirus pandemic began, and masks will be mandatory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conrad de Aenlle
title: Stock Market Drop Accelerated as Recession Seemed More Likely
description: Further losses may be on the way, even after a 20 percent drop in the first half of the year, as Wall Street continues to price in the Fed’s aggressive interest rate policy.
content: Investors had an awful start to the year as stocks twice entered bear market territory, falling more than 20 percent. Stocks didn’t hang there long the first time, but the second drop has proved more durable, as Wall Street has come to accept that inflation is more persistent and that the Federal Reserve will have to be more aggressive in combating it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Californians Share Their Favorite Farmers’ Markets
description: It isn’t just about the produce.
content: With so many of us working remotely and our social lives still somewhat disrupted by the pandemic, there’s a particular comfort in seeing the same faces every week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti and Jeanna Smialek
title: Retail sales rise more than expected, keeping pressure on the Fed.
description: Central bank officials are watching closely for signs that the economy is running hot, stoking inflation, and strong spending in June could push them closer to a bigger interest rate increase.
content: Retail sales rose 1 percent in June, more than expected, reversing a decline in the previous month, the Commerce Department reported Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Capturing the Cosmos
description: Turning distant galaxies into sound.
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: ‘Sometimes I Am Crying in the Room’
description: An Olympic medalist high jumper from Ukraine, fearful of returning home because of the war, arrives at the world championships with a heavy heart — and expectations to win.
content: BRNO, Czech Republic — It was an unusual place to hold a high-jump competition — a parking lot outside a shopping mall in late June. Customers stopped briefly with their bags. A cluster of spectators, including Ukrainian war refugees finding a moment to cheer, stood along a railing. Human statues, painted gold, froze in poses as ancient Olympians. Cars and trucks whisked south on the highway toward Slovakia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Eric Adams Can’t Stop Talking About Crime. There Are Risks to That.

content: Murders and shootings are down in New York City this year. But you might not know it if you listen to the city’s mayor, Eric Adams.

title: Migraine Treatment Has Come a Long Way
description: This ‘woman’s disease’ doesn’t get a lot of research funding, but the medical establishment has made strides in developing new drugs and devices to combat migraine over the last five years.
content: If you don’t suffer from migraine headaches, you probably know at least one person who does. Nearly 40 million Americans get them — 28 million of them women and girls — making migraine the second most disabling condition in the world after low back pain. Several studies have found that migraine became more frequent during the pandemic, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fresh Data Give Fed Wiggle Room on Rates at July Meeting

content: Officials at the Federal Reserve have been speaking out in favor of a three-quarter-point interest rate increase at their meeting this month, while leaving open the possibility of a larger move if economic data came in especially strong. Fresh economic figures released Friday could give them reason to move in either direction.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Monkeypox Catches New York City Off Guard (Again)

content: Over the past month, the number of people identified with monkeypox in New York City has jumped more than 30 fold, from 10 to 336, a figure that surely underestimates the incidence rate, considering that many cases have gone undiagnosed. During this period, Mayor Eric Adams was busy celebrating Pride, holding a party at Gracie mansion and reminding the world just how deeply New York embraces the L.G.B.T.Q. community, while so many other parts of the country seem bent on a regression to the pre-Stonewall era.
